Award.AwardTitle: "Reclaiming the American Dream" A Scholarship Program for Community College Transfer Students in Biology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project provides scholarships to 30 students to obtain baccalaureate degrees in biology at the University of Miami following transfer from Miami Dade College. It builds on an established and successful transfer program between a community college and a research university and ensures that academically talented scholars have financial and other support to persist and excel in regionally and nationally important STEM fields. In addition to scholarships, students are being supported comprehensively through seminars and professional-development workshops, faculty advising, peer mentoring, research and conference opportunities, and parental/family outreach. The intellectual merit of this project lies in the well-planned activities and strong collaborative relationship between the partnering institutions. The broader impact lies in promoting STEM degree attainment by high-ability, financially needy students, many first in family to attend college and/or from underrepresented minorities. The project is also serving as a model for other institutions in achieving transformation, not only for the individual students, but in integrating an undertapped pool of talent into the broader scientific and economic enterprise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes:

The Reclaiming the American Dream Scholarship Program supports academically talented, economically disadvantaged community college transfer students at the University of Miami (UM). Eighty percent of our RAD scholars are Pell Grant eligible, 74% are members of an underrepresented (UR) minority group, and approximately half are first-generation college students. RAD scholars are awarded an annual $10,000 tuition scholarship for two years and provided with academic and psychosocial support.

A total of 39 students received RAD scholarships during this grant period. Thirteen are still enrolled at UM and are making satisfactory progress toward their B.S. degree. Of the other 26 students, 24 (92%) graduated with a STEM degree and two withdrew from the university without graduating. Of the students who graduated, 29% (7/24) are pursuing a STEM Ph.D. degree, 33% (8/24) are employed in a STEM industry, and 4% (1/24) pursued a PREP program. The other 38% (9/24) students have chosen to pursue clinical or non-STEM career paths.

Intellectual Merit: RAD scholars have indicated that the most effective activity of the program is the research experience. Scholars overwhelmingly reported during a focus group that the program research activities prepared them to continue working toward a research career. The graduation rate for students who have conducted research is 95% (20/21), while the graduation rate of those who have not conducted research is 83% (4/5). This indicates that research experiences contribute to the persistence of community college transfer students in STEM.

Broader Impacts: The RAD program is helping to level the STEM playing field by providing educational resources for economically disadvantaged students in Miami. Miami Dade College (MDC) has a rich pool of academically talented students from low-income and ethnically diverse families who we recruit to our RAD program. The partnership between UM and MDC can serve as a model for other four-year and two-year institutional collaborations working to increase diversity in STEM.
